PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF SENATOR ALAN JOSEPH MISSEN

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform honourable senators of the death on 30 March of Senator Alan Missen, who served Australia and Victoria with great distinction in this place from May 1974 to March 1986. As a founding member of the Liberal Party of Australia, his contribution to the development of post-war politics in this country was substantial. Last Friday, 4 April, together with a number of our colleagues, the Acting Clerk of the Senate and the Usher of the Black Rod, I attended Senator Missen's funeral and conveyed the deepest sympathy of all senators to his widow, Mollie.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Missen was a highly regarded and respected member of the Senate. He was a consistent and uncompromising civil libertarian and the stands he took on many issues in this chamber were also based on the highest of principles. I had the honour of serving with him on a number of parliamentary committees in which capacity he also gave unstinting and untiring service. He will be greatly missed by all of us who had the fortune to know him and to serve with him in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on 30 March 1986, of Senator Alan Joseph Missen, a Senator for the State of Victoria from 1974 and a former Chairman of a number of Senate Committees, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service, and tenders its profound sympathy to his widow in her bereavement.

Alan Missen was an outstanding parliamentarian who made a great contribution to his political party, this Parliament and our country. Insofar as I speak today on behalf of the Government, I want to acknowledge and applaud his distinguished career, his personal charm and character, his tolerance and his humanity. I do not wish to dwell on that career because it is well documented in newspapers, in Hansard and, in the minutes of a dozen organisations espousing noble causes and will be further recorded in speeches made here today. Rather, I want to pay a personal tribute, and memoir in a sense, to Alan Missen that of necessity must be somewhat anecdotal.

Our life paths were in some ways parallel, at times closing together and intersecting and at times being much wider apart and diverse. We first met in 1951 at the time of the referendum seeking to outlaw the Communist Party. At that time Alan Missen was President of the Young Liberals in Victoria and I was president of nothing and but a junior member of the Australian Labor Party. We grew to know each other quite well then and over subsequent years we saw quite a bit of each other. I debated with him under the auspices of the Victorian Debating Society. I remind the Senate what a formidable team Alan Missen and his wife Mollie constituted when they were in a debate together. I learnt that to my great cost quite early in my career.

We entered the Senate together in 1974. On the hustings we held many more debates which I must say were always characterised by great fairness on both sides and I believe that was because Alan Missen set the tone of those debates. We worked together on a number of community issues such as trying to help the Timorese refugee community in Melbourne and things like that where I learnt to admire his great dedication and organisational skills. I have referred to his debating talents and of course I believe that he always carried out his role as a parliament- arian in a similar, very fair way. Last week a very senior Minister in this Government in the House of Representatives who hardly knew Alan Missen said to me `that Alan Missen seems to have been a very good bloke' and I said `Yes'. He said: `You know, he drove me mad asking me questions about various issues but they were always the right questions'. I think that, in its own way, is a very humble but simple tribute to Alan Missen's career.

On Friday last I attended his funeral in Melbourne. It was a moving service and eloquent tributes were paid to him by his political colleagues. I think perhaps the most moving compliment of all was shown by the wide selection of community groups and interests which were represented at that funeral. Afterwards, standing outside, a grey figure amongst other grey politicians, a young man approached me and invited me to join Amnesty International. I was shocked to find that he did not know I was a member of Amnesty International but, of course, everybody knew that Alan Missen was. I spoke with representatives of the Timorese community. A lady from Sri Lanka came up to me and said: `Senator, now that Alan Missen is dead, please do not forget the plight of the Tamil people because there is a danger that it will be forgotten now that he is gone'. Of course, that is a danger which we all ought to think about and try to avoid. I knew what these people were talking about because, at the saddest time of my life Alan Missen and his wife Mollie stretched out to me a hand of friendship which I will never forget.

Alan Missen was a warm human being of many talents. His life and work were unfettered by the constraints which motivate most of us in politics and in this profession, if I can call it that. They are the constraints imposed by ambition and the sorts of fierce tribal loyalties which we develop in a place such as this. Alan was a refreshing free spirit and every society and every group needs one. He will be very greatly missed. I think the best thing is for those of us who remain to remember the things he stood so courageously for. On behalf of the Government, members of my Party and particularly myself, I wish to extend deepest sympathy to his wife Mollie and to acknowledge a great career.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I support the motion of condolence which has been moved by Senator Button on behalf of the Government and I thank him for the words that he has spoken about Alan Missen and the personal remarks which he made about him. As far as members of the Opposition are concerned we have lost a valued colleague, we have lost a friend and, of course, the whole Senate has lost an outstanding parliamentarian. I think it is worth making some reference to the formal record of Alan Missen's participation in the Senate since 1974. The record discloses the central interests which he had and which he pursued very strongly whilst he was there and, indeed, long before he came to Parliament. He was involved with the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances for much of his time here and with committees such as the Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills, and with the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for the whole of his term in the Senate. He served on the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act which continued work that he had done on the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee and which made use of his extensive professional knowledge in that area. He worked both within Australia and outside Australia with respect to the parliamentary control of delegated legislation. As the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) has said, he had a very close and long connection with the Australian parliamentary group of Amnesty International. He was a former President of the Australian Debating Federation. He was recently a member of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority and he was a National Vice-President of the International Commission of Jurists, to mention just a few of the activities for which he was well known. That bare record shows his consistent interests in and concerns for civil liberties, the oppressed and deprived, the law and the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: His final contributions in the Senate were typical of his record here. He sponsored amendments preserving part time representation on the Human Rights Commission. He was not seeking to make a technical point; he was aiming to prevent the bureaucratisation of that body and to keep it in touch with the realities of human rights. He also sought, successfully, to have State representation on that Commission. His maiden speech in this place, in August 1974, was on trade practices legislation. It is an unusual maiden speech because it is not concerned with broad questions of principle but rather with particular technical concerns which Senator Missen had about the legislation, and it is therefore typical of one aspect of his work-his assiduous attention to detail which marked him out among senators. I would like to quote a couple of simple sentences because they could be applied again and again to his contributions in this place. After referring to the fact that the legislation had significant consequences for the people and industries of the country, he said that the legislation:
. . . consequently should be considered very carefully . . . The amendments which have already been foreshadowed by the Opposition will I think improve the legislation.

He took very seriously from the time of that maiden speech his role as a senator to improve the legislation which goes through this place often without very many senators' or members' eyes being cast over it. He made his last speech on the plight of refugees, and that was no doubt the most appropriate way that he could have ended his parliamentary career. He referred on the second last day he was here, during the debate that we have on matters of public interest, to the tragedy which had beset various refugee Afghan people. He quoted a former soldier of the Soviet Union as saying:
The tragedy of the Afghan nation is made worse by the silence of world public opinion.

That is a useful sentence to remember because Alan Missen was always concerned to make sure that tragedies were not forgotten and that public opinion would not be silent. I found when reading that speech yet another organisation with which he was connected. He was the patron of the Australian Relief Committee for Afghanistan. Only Alan could have adopted that role.

I do not think that Senator Missen was unique in his interests but he was remarkable for his consistent and detailed application to his interests and concerns. His membership of committees and other organisations was never formal; it was never a matter of mere attendance. He gave assiduous attention to the details and to the facts, and he formed his views and stood by them. He was utterly consistent in that, whether his party was in opposition or in government. We all received many contributions from him in the form of his opinions and his research findings. He would issue after each Senate sitting a report on that sitting and distribute it widely. I was sorry to reread his last summary and find him expressing a gloomy view of the Senate's present activities and its failure to scrutinise government legislation and regulations, and I hope that we will honour his memory by living up to his request that the Senate perform that role better in the future than it has in the past.

I thought that another good example of his work would appeal to the previous Labor Attorney-General, Senator Evans who, having so often found him an ally, often also found him to be an opponent when he was Attorney-General. I found that in 1981 he issued to his Liberal colleagues, and no doubt to his National Party colleagues, a paper entitled `The Seven Deadly Sins of Omission' from the Federal Government's 1981 Freedom of Information Bill. If he gave Liberal Ministers a hard time in what he saw as their sometimes dragging their feet on freedom of information, I have to say that I was greatly consoled when he gave the same hard time to Senator Gareth Evans and to his successor on the same issue.

The enormous interest Alan Missen showed in the attack on organised crime was a more recent feature of his life and work, and his determination that there should be strong and effective measures some saw at odds with his considerable concern for civil liberties. It is worth mentioning that at this time, because it is a reminder of how fatuous it often is to label people. Alan Missen bore the label civil libertarian and I think he properly bore it, and some thought he lost an entitlement to it when he thought that organised crime was such a serious problem that it required significantly strong measures. I thought that it was an interesting facet of Alan's ability to look at the facts and to analyse them, and not to be locked into a position, that he took the strong stance he did. I would like to quote briefly from something he said in 1985 about organised crime, because it is very relevant today. Many senators would have heard the ex-royal commissioners Moffitt, Woodward, Costigan and Williams speaking on this subject as recently as yesterday. Senator Missen said:

I don't think many people really understand the extent of organised crime in this country. I don't think they appreciate that basic civil liberties are about having a country free of corrupt officials, a country where you can go to the judges and use the proper processes of law.

There was a lot more he said in that field that is worth quoting, and I hope will be quoted. To me it was a significant and important part of his more recent years as a member of this place, and as a politician.

A lot of people will speak about Alan today and I limit my contribution in acknowledgment of that. I make just a couple of personal references. I first served with him on the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, and it was there that I learned to admire his dedication to work and his sincere concern for his principles. I later saw him bring into operation the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. That was important to me because it was an idea I had fostered and then, as a member of the Government, had to oppose. I saw him introduce it notwithstanding the opposition of the then Government and show that it worked and would contribute to the legislative process. I am grateful to him for that particular contribution.

I, as a member of Amnesty International but one of the less known and I would say deservedly less known members, like the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) admired Alan Missen's work and activity on behalf of prisoners of conscience of whom, sadly, there are far too many around the world. We became friends through our work together. I worked with him as a colleague as Senate Whip and as Leader of the Opposition. I suppose it would be because I was Senate Whip that I feel I can say that I acknowledge that as a friend and as a colleague he was sometimes difficult, because of the strength of his views and his convictions on issues, but he was a man who did not let issues override friendship, and I am grateful to him for that.

As has been said by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Missen had a talented wife. She was a loyal and devoted wife and she has our love and sympathy. They shared a great deal; the debating that was mentioned by Senator Button and many other things. She will miss him and, on behalf of the Opposition, I express our sympathy to her and our affection for him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the National Party of Australia, I join the mover and seconder of this motion of condolence on the death of our departed colleague Alan Missen. As Senator Chaney said, and indeed as was mentioned in some of the moving tributes in the service that I was privileged to attend on behalf of the National Party on Friday, Alan was a difficult friend. I suppose I would be less than honest if I did not say that the National Party in this place found Alan's relationship with us at times difficult. Having said that, I think it is one of the signs of maturity in this chamber that it is not long before one looks beyond the philosophical veneers with which we cloak ourselves when we come in here and sees what it is that motivates a man. It has already been mentioned that the motivation which kept Alan going with such intensity was human rights and civil rights, which I suppose could all be summed up in the phrase, the dignity of man. In the pursuit of that Alan was unwavering. He was affronted by racism, by bigotry and by unjust imprisonment-all those things that he thought and, indeed, knew degraded the life of a human being. He was affronted by organised crime.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button mentioned Alan's debating abilities. He was, indeed, a good debater. He was not aggressive but he was certainly thoughtful, thorough and intense. He was first and foremost a parliamentarian and secondly a politician. His committee work will be here long after our memory of Alan is gone because the work he did on committees and in the formation of some of them-as Senator Chaney said, even against his Government-will be there as a fitting memorial for him. We will all benefit from the work that he put into those committees for years to come.

I suppose one could also say that Alan was a loner because of all those things we have mentioned. He was a loner, not because he was anti-social or because he did not like the friendship of his colleagues, but basically because he saw things differently. I guess we see them in a philosophical way, a State's way, a national way or an international way, but Alan reduced them not to their simplistic forms but more or less to their human terms. That is how he saw everything and judged everything. I suppose one could say that he was idealistic as well as being altruistic. I could not help thinking of that during the service when for the final hymn we sung those words of Blake's set to Parry's beautiful rendition of Jerusalem:
Bring me my bow of burning gold!
Bring me my arrows of desire!
Bring me my spear! O clouds, unfold!
Bring me my chariot of fire!
I shall not cease from Mental Fight,
Nor shall my Sword sleep in my hand,
Till we have built Jerusalem,
In England's green and pleasant Land.

I suppose Alan's whole life revolved around building that new Jerusalem. Significantly, the New Testament lesson was also on that theme-from Revelation 21. His building of the new Jerusalem did not know any national boundaries, but it was certainly his motivating force. It demanded all of his being and ultimately demanded and took his life.
Mr President, the National Party would like to be associated with all the remarks today and to extend sympathy to Mollie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I join the Australian Democrats with the motion of condolence moved by Senator Button and supported by other senators. We want to place on record our deep regret at the passing of Senator Missen. Although I, as Leader of the Party, am pleased and honoured to give my Party's support to this motion, Senator Haines and Senator Mason, who had special reasons to admire and respect Senator Missen, will also be looking for your call later in this tribute.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it quite salutary to recall that on the last day of sitting of this Senate-20 March-I was standing in this place making a contribution to some debate when I heard a familiar voice from a seat nearby interjecting about what I was saying. As was usual with Senator Missen, his interjections were never made to score a cheap political point or to be a smart-alick. The interjection, which I acknowledged, was made to try to be helpful and to try to improve the tone of debate in this place. Here I am, on the first day of this sitting fortnight, standing up, and I reflect that I was not dreaming in a million years, when I stood here just one sitting day ago, that Senator Missen would not be alive and active in this place today. That brings home to us the significance of our existence and the relatively short time that we have in which to make a real contribution to our fellow human beings while we are here. We can do a lot worse in pursuing that aim than looking at the standard of excellence set by Alan Missen in that endeavour. He was a man with a well deserved reputation for supporting the underdog and the oppressed. He was a true small `l' liberal, who staunchly followed the principles of John Stuart Mill. He was widely and properly recognised as a man of great courage.

I worked with Alan Missen in the Liberal Party for many years and I recall with great pleasure the many battles that he and I fought in that Party, sometimes just the two of us, and I remember that he was a good and honourable companion to have in a battle. In the Senate, since I came here in 1978, I have had the pleasure of serving with him on many committees, including the memorable committee that helped to save the Franklin River from extinction. I suppose that one of the greatest tributes that one could pay to Alan Missen would be to say-those of us who have worked with him would agree-that he could never be taken for granted; that he was always his own person. He was always a person of ultimate intellectual capacity, who would hear evidence on a point and then make up his own mind irrespective of what kind of pressures were applied to him.

Alan Missen will be greatly missed in this place, for both his personal and his intellectual capacities, and, indeed, for his international reputation for the championing of human rights, and that will ensure that his special qualities remain as a worthy example for others to follow. I, too, pay a tribute to his delightful wife Mollie. Like Senator Button, I, too, have been engaged in debates with her. Fortunately for me-unlike Senator Button-I was always smart enough to be on her side. She is a delightful person. On behalf of my Party, I send condolences to her at this sad time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like everyone else in this Parliament, I am asked occasionally why it is that people become politicians; what is it that drives us or motivates us to put up with the hostility and the cynicism, with the perhaps limited financial rewards-at least as compared to those of some of the professions, such as Alan Missen's, the law-and with the crazy, health-destroying hours and pressures that are our lot. My short and, perhaps, rather glib standard answer to that sort of question has always been that there are two basic motivations that I can discern in all of us who become politicians, to a greater or a lesser extent-there is megalomania, and there is idealism. The proportions might vary quite dramatically from case to case but elements of both are always present. I have to say that the life and parliamentary career of Alan Missen constituted, I think, the extreme limiting case for that theory. If there was any element of power hunger about Alan, he kept it extremely well hidden. He was absolutely, unequivocally and uncompromisingly an idealist-right over at the far, idealistic end of the political spectrum.

SPEECH.PARA: Alan Missen believed intensely and passionately, as has been said, in an immense variety of humane and worthy ideals and causes, both within Australia and overseas. He fought valiantly and heroically against abuses of civil liberty wherever he found them. He fought for decency and respect for human rights and for justice, not only in a long list of individual cases but also in the way in which institutions and systems of government operate. He did have a long view, and the microcases that he pursued were almost invariably the vehicle for some or other macro reform that he was also pursuing. In fighting his causes, Alan was indefatigably and sometimes infuriatingly persistent-infuriating, when one felt, as his friends on both sides of politics sometimes did, that he had grabbed some particular bull by the wrong horn and could not, or would not, be persuaded to see that particular cause in some more balanced light. He certainly stretched his friendship with me on a couple of occasions during the long and vigorous war that he waged, as Senator Chaney has already mentioned, against the Government in general and me in particular on the organised crime issue, when we each regarded the other as adopting thoroughly misguided and perverse positions.

But that friendship was never in any real danger at all of rupture, and nor was the immense respect I had for him over many years as a person and a parliamentarian, because there was always so much that was just, fearless and admirable about him, always so much that was worthwhile about the causes that he espoused. Let us think about those causes: Freedom from political oppression in every country, whatever its ideological makeup, which he pursued, of course, through Amnesty International; the cause of the protection of liberty in the legislative process, concerns which are more often, I suppose, in this society casually overlooked than deliberately ignored, but which are ignored nonetheless and which need mechanisms to correct them and which Alan pursued in his role, as has been said, as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, the new Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs and all other forms of procedures in this place; the cause of improvement in the quality of public administration, which he pursued through a number of different kinds of campaigns, but none more effective than that which resulted in freedom of information legislation, an issue on which, as has already been indicated, at least in principle Alan and I saw exactly eye to eye, which made us both rather solitary figures within our respective parties from time to time, particularly when we were in government; the cause of improvements in our constitutional system, which Alan vigorously pursued in a variety of forums, not least in his co-patronage with Don Chipp and me of the Campaign for Constitutional Change, one of those numerous causes which did not get very far off the ground, it has to be acknowledged; the causes of improvement in the quality of life for individuals to the extent that that can be achieved through reforms to the law and the legal process. Again, there was no achievement more considerable, I guess, over all the years in this respect than what he did and was able to influence so far as family law was concerned.

I guess that one of the issues for which Alan Missen will longest be remembered, and certainly that which endeared him, perhaps more than anything else to those on this side of the chamber, was the stand he took on the proper role of the Senate during the 1975 constitutional crisis. There has been a tendency in this place to reserve the label of good senator, good Senate man or great Senate man for those who have made it an article of faith that this institution should or must have the kind of overweening powers in relation to the House of Representatives claimed for it in 1975. Alan Missen did not ever believe that the Senate should have the power to block Supply or in any other way to destroy the capacity to govern of the properly elected government of the day. But he was, in the fullest possible sense of the description, a great senator, a great Senate man.

Alan, I believe, had exactly the right perception of the proper role and function of the Senate in our constitutional system, not as a House of destruction but as a constructive House of review dedicated to improving the quality of legislation, scrutinising the Executive Government, monitoring the bureaucracy, and acting, particularly through its committee system, as a springboard for ideas. Alan used all the avenues and procedures available to him as a senator to the fullest; exercising all those roles but also enhancing the way in which those roles were exercised by the institution as a whole in the work that he did as chairman, and founding father in many instances, of those various committees.

Let me finally say that Alan Missen had, as most of us do, a number of disappointments during his political life, none greater, I suppose, than his not making the front bench, even when the climate was perhaps a little more receptive to his particular brand of Liberalism than it is at the moment. In particular, there was his disappointment at not getting to be either shadow Attorney-General or Attorney-General, jobs for which he was eminently well qualified-although I kept telling him that the job of Attorney-General was not really all that it was cracked up to be. But there was no need in reality for him ever to feel disappointed about what he accomplished in his career in this place because those monuments are, as has been said, all around in legislation such as the Family Law Act and the Freedom of Information Act, to which he massively contributed, in the reports of the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee under his chairmanship, in the international standing and credibility, as again has been said, of our Regulations and Ordinances Committee and Scrutiny of Bills Committee which he brought either to existence or to maturity with the work under his leadership, along with the pages of Hansard in which he pursued issue after issue with great debating skill and merciless enthusiasm.

Mollie, to whom all our hearts go out at this terrible time for her, can be very proud of Alan for everything he stood for and accomplished. I am certainly proud to have known him, to have been able to work so closely with him over so many years across political boundaries on so many issues dear to both him and me, and to have been able to call him friend. Alan Missen was a fine, spirited, independent and idealistic soul. There have not been very many like him in Australian politics, and there will not be again. I mourn his passing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion of condolence moved by Senator Button and supported by Senator Chaney and other senators on this very sad occasion when we speak and are present in memory of Alan Missen. I had not known Alan for as long as had Senator Button or Senator Chipp, but during the years that he and I served in the Senate since he first came in 1974 I was very closely associated with a number of the issues and ideals which were very dear to Alan's heart. I met him some time before he came to the Senate when we were on a Party committee looking at policy matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will not be surprised to know that the policy that we were discussing was freedom of information. At that stage, he was endeavouring to develop a policy for the Liberal Party of Australia on that important subject. I frankly concede that the work of that committee and particularly Alan's enthusiasm for that subject and the strong arguments that he presented first interested me in freedom of information. A few years later, when Alan came to the Senate, he pursued that subject with great vigour, as he did many other causes.

The cover of the brochure at the funeral service referred to Alan Missen as senator for Victoria and champion of human rights. That was a most apt description but, of course, he was a champion of many causes other than human rights, although one can define that matter in very wide terms. I suppose that a great many of his causes clearly came within the term of human rights and he pursued them, as we know, with great vigour. He also had a great many other interests, causes and ideals. For instance, he was interested in and strongly supported environmental issues. He pursued them with the same sense of purpose and idealism as human rights. He was interested in a surprising number of different issues.

As Senator Chaney said, Alan Missen's maiden speech was on an amendment to the Trade Practices Act, which seems to be very removed, particularly on the technical side, from his usual human rights interests. Above all, Alan was an issues person. He was really interested only in the success of the policies that he pursued. He certainly did not pursue his political career with any obvious personal ambition or to obtain power although he succeeded overwhelmingly because of the power of ideas and the strong purpose with which he pursued those ideas. Although he may not have been seen to be a politician who sought power, he did achieve it and, I think, he was entitled to believe that he had succeeded in many areas simply because of the force of his ideas and the vigour with which he pursued them.

As I have said, Alan and I worked together on a number of matters which were very dear to his heart, both in government and opposition. We had many differences in respect of those matters but I believe that the differences we had were ones of means, not ends. He always sought fulfilment of the ideal, the full purpose of the policy that he espoused. He was not very interested in compromising and that always makes it difficult in politics, which is so much about the art of compromise. I sometimes wondered whether he felt dissatisfied. He achieved many of his purposes by the strength with which he pursued them and the persuasion that he exercised. Many of the issues that he pursued were ultimately on the statute book in one form or another and freedom of information is an obvious example. Human rights legislation and a whole series of legislation that this Parliament has enacted over the last decade in relation to the rights of people against the Government, the Executive and administrative review in one form or another are all very much due to the strong support that he always gave them. Thus he had every reason to feel that he achieved his purposes. As I have said, I hope that he got satisfaction from that, although one often wondered whether he did. He always seemed to have something of the divine discontent about him, the hallmark of the artist and I suppose of the idealist, but I think he achieved a great deal.

Two characteristics impressed me greatly. They stood out in a very glowing way and perhaps compensated for some of the difficulties there were in working with him. One was the effort he put into anything he did. He was a very, very hard worker. He worked long hours and effectively. He never seemed to stint himself. His was an outstanding career and an example to us all of what can be done by dedication and hard work; of course, bringing to bear his own great abilities. He had many great abilities and he put them to the best use at all times.

The other characteristic which impressed me greatly was his integrity. He would always tell a person what he felt; he would always say when he disagreed and he would always say when he intended to take a different view, whether that be in the private councils of the Party, in this chamber or at other public platforms. Those two characteristics stood out and for some people who worked with him they were great compensation for the differences that sometimes-in fact very often-occurred. I believe he did wear himself out. Of course, he died unexpectedly and very suddenly. He may well have lived longer if he had looked after himself more. From talking to Mollie, I think she felt that too, but she understood why he did it. Of course, it is a great sadness for her that the man that she loved so much and supported so splendidly all his life was lost to her at an earlier age than perhaps otherwise would have been the case. But he got his satisfaction from continuing with the work that contributed to his death at an earlier age than perhaps would have been the case in other circumstances. I am sure that he was pleased to pursue and got his satisfaction from pursuing those great ideals in the great work that he did. His widow, Mollie, to whom we all extend our deepest sympathy today, understood that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a fellow member of the rather large class of 1974 in this place, I would like to say a few words of respect for the late Alan Missen. As my colleague John Button has said, Alan Missen was a free spirit. If he was ambitious for power or position in this place, he never let any of us know that and he certainly did not seem to allow any such ambition to be a constraint on his activities in this place in what he said and did and in the issues that he followed up.

SPEECH.PARA: He was unusual enough, I suppose, in the Australian political context in that he was an intellectual politician and took an intellectual approach to what he did. But that intellectual approach was tempered by compassion-compassion for those who through no fault of their own or otherwise were less well off than the rest of us; compassion for those who were oppressed internationally or in this country; compassion for anyone he thought was treated unfairly. As a Minister for Social Security, I frequently heard from Alan Missen about people he thought were treated unfairly in that narrow sphere. But, as well as being compassionate, he pushed the ideas that he had and the issues that he felt strongly about with great passion. He could get extremely passionate in Amnesty International about those matters that he took seriously and he frequently spoke in the adjournment debates in this place on matters that were of importance not just to him and his State, not just to him and his own political career, but to the whole nation.

I am pleased to have known Alan Missen and to have served with him on the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. I remember one memorable occasion when the majority decision of that Committee was put down by Senators Missen, Chaney, Button and Grimes and the minority opinion by Senators Wright and Everett. That was an extraordinarily difficult thing. I am sure that Senators Chaney, Button and Grimes would not have had the courage to put down that decision without the strength and intellectual capacity of Senator Missen to assist. As I have said, I am very pleased to have known him and to have been in this chamber and this Parliament with him. Victoria has lost a very fine senator. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.
SPEECH.PARA: When beggars die there are no comets seen. The heavens themselves blaze forth the death of princes.

I thought of those words of Shakespeare the other evening while looking for the comet because it struck me that among classical liberals there was no one more entitled to call himself the prince than Alan Missen. Today there is more than simply an empty chair beside me; there is a void in the Australian body politic and a very empty space in my heart. Alan and I were soul mates going back to my teenage years. Indeed, even in my parliamentary career, the first day that I came into this Parliament I sat next to Alan Missen. The last day he was in the chamber we were sitting together. Indeed, he was a touch-stone for me in terms of philosophy and of principle. I was never embarrassed to play the role of Sancho Panza to his Don Quixote, for Alan was indeed a great tilter at windmills, both real and imagined and both actual and potential. It was occasionally difficult to stand here and make a speech and have Alan Missen sitting beside me muttering under his breath: `You have sold out again, haven't you?' But perhaps the balance of megalomania and idealism is different in me than it was in Alan.

In his fight for justice and for human rights, Alan was totally indiscriminating. Whether it was in Kabul, Dili, Santiago, Addis Ababa, Aurukun, Moscow, Jaffna or Soweto, it made absolutely no difference to Alan. I remember one of my very senior Party colleagues at one stage telling me: `The problem with Alan Missen is that he thinks he is the only person in the chamber with a conscience'. Perhaps the real test was that he was the only one in the chamber who had never learned how to suppress it entirely under all circumstances. He said on many occasions that his ideal was Gladstone-not that he was taken to wandering streets at night, but that he genuinely believed that he became more liberal as he got older.

Perhaps his greatest memorial will be what takes place around us in this Senate chamber. Of all the things that he achieved, it is his achievements as a parliamentarian which really need to be highlighted. All honourable senators who have so far spoken have talked about his work on the Freedom of Information legislation designed to redress the balance between citizen and government. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has been mentioned. Perhaps one should remind oneself that both the Freedom of Information legislation and the Scrutiny of Bills legislation were pieces of legislation that he was prepared to pursue to the point of crossing the floor. But his work on the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, his work on delegated legislation, his chairmanship of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs which brought down a report on delegated legislation, his appointment as the first ever chairman of the international conference on delegated legislation, and his work on the revision of privilege and the defence of privileges of citizens were all matters of enormous significance. His work on the National Crimes Monitoring Committee proposals was also designed to ensure the adequate protection of individuals. If I may return to Shakespeare's Julius Caesar, he was a bit like Brutus, not only the noblest Roman of them all but perhaps seeking to restore the older and perhaps indeed imaginary and purer days against the caesarism of the Executive of whatever political colour.

The width of his interests was enormous, whether in law reform or the environment. His work in relation to the Great Barrier Reef and the Tasmanian dams issue persuaded him that he probably needed a visa for at least two States of Australia. I mention his work in the conservation movement as a member of Project Jonah and as the honorary solicitor for more than a quarter of a century for the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and his absolutely outstanding record on human rights. Perhaps above all, even in the case of an individual, such as William Sinclair who could find nobody else to speak for him and everybody else ready to condemn, Alan believed in that individual and went to the most extraordinary lengths to seek justice for him and to seek redress.

As a member of Amnesty International he was enormously concerned with the rights of people in this country and around the world. It is perhaps ironic that, even in the normal course of events, he would not have been in the chamber today. In fact, he would have been in Rome as the Deputy Chairman of the Amnesty International panel on Sri Lanka. It had invited him there once again to report to the international community his findings on the civil liberties question in that country. But, above all, I suppose that Alan would have wanted to have been remembered as a liberal, a small `l' liberal, or indeed as he once told a university audience, as a capital `T' trendy. He had a philosophical commitment to liberalism. He opposed socialism because he thought that it did not give the sort of recognition to the individual human spirit that he believed in and for exactly the same purposes and for exactly the same reasons he rejected conservatism because he thought that that was predicated on a belief that individuals could do nothing which, in turn, was predicated upon a loss of faith in oneself. Alan never lost faith either in other individuals, no matter what the empirical evidence to the contrary, or indeed in himself. I think the most definitive statement of his beliefs was delivered in a speech to the Politics Club of the University of New South Wales on 31 August 1981. The speech was entitled `The Liberal Struggle against the Politics of Fear'. Having surveyed the world an international political and philosophical trends, Alan gave a ringing conclusion endorsing the liberal spirit. He said that Liberals must develop long-range economic vision for Australia and that they must reject all those things which sought to bind or limit them. He said that people had to look at how it was that the human spirit could be liberated not just in a philosophical sense but also in an economic sense and he concluded with these words:
Liberals must look at reform in this country, whether it be the removal of injustice or anomalies or the updating of our Constitution, as urgent tasks worthy of much effort.

I do not believe there is ground for despair, but rather for optimism in the assets, ingenuity and growth of the Australian people. The politics of fear has been a temporary phenomenon in democratic societies-let us take all necessary steps to move it on its way.

All that he did he did with great passion. Perhaps the only consoling thing about his early death is that the passion continued to the very end. I extend my personal tribute to Mollie-an expression of my sympathy which she knows I mean most sincerely. For those of us who are left to go on, the late Alan Missen will be a constant touchstone and inspiration. He knew, I suppose, the essential difference between the principle of compromise and the compromise of principle. We will not let his cause falter nor his banners lie in the dust. I bid farewell to this man of principle, this gentle, intense, kind and passionate soul, by turning to the words spoken by Mark Antony in the play Julius Caesar as he stood over the body of the fallen noble Brutus. He said:
His life was gentle, and the elements so mix'd in him that nature might stand up and say to all the world-`This was a man'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to be associated with the condolence motion moved so ably by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), seconded by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) and supported by such a wide variety of speakers today. It is a sad day that the Senate is meeting and deliberating without Alan Missen. It is a sad day because we have lost a very human, a very compassionate and a very decent human being as well as one of the Parliament's best contributors to all the issues that have been referred to by many of those who have spoken. This is the fourth occasion that I can recall in the 15 years that I have been here that we have adjourned the Senate due to the death of a sitting senator. The other occasions were due to the deaths of Senator Milliner, Senator Greenwood and Senator Knight. I think it is a tribute to the late Senator Missen that he was respected by a large number of people who have written articles in the newspapers and have made contributions to the condolence motion today.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been said, Alan was a person of strong liberal views which were distinctly different from the conservative views which existed within his own Party. In that sense he had a deep and unflinching commitment to a whole range of issues, such as civil liberties, human rights throughout the world, liberalism in the small `l' sense, constitutional proprieties, legal reform and an active government role in the social and economic affairs of our country. This commitment led him to champion a number of causes, often causes of a minority view. As I reflect on it I can endorse most of those causes. Even though we often differed on how we would achieve those objectives and, despite our opposite positions, we were nevertheless able to come to a common position on a wider range of issues. One of these issues or causes was his blanket opposition to capital punishment.

Before his death one of his last acts was to lead a delegation in his capacity as Chairman of the Australian Parliamentary Group of Amnesty International to protest against the continuation of capital punishment in three countries. When we look at those three countries-the People's Republic of China, Iran and the United States of America-we see the common position that we can take in respect of that issue. There was his early and outspoken opposition to apartheid long before that issue enjoyed wide and commanding support in the Australian community. He publicly reinforced that commitment last year when he spoke against the changes in policy on that issue in the Victorian Liberal Party. Senator Puplick and others have referred to the fact that he took up a whole range of issues concerning matters such as the Great Barrier Reef and the Franklin River. He took a public position on such environmental issues. He expressed his continued support for public ownership of institutions such as the Commonwealth Bank, Telecom Australia and Australia Post. He is on the public record as supporting a means-based welfare system to ensure that benefits were concentrated on the needy and the deserving.

Other speakers have referred to his staunch opposition to the Communist Party Dissolution Bill in the 1950s and the pain that that must have caused him when disciplinary action was taken against him by his Party. Most importantly he endorsed the right of the party which enjoyed the confidence of the House of Representatives to govern and he opposed the Senate's withholding of Supply from the Government-a view which he reiterated only four months ago on the tenth anniversary of the dismissal of the Whitlam Government, not because he supported the policies of the Whitlam Government but because of the important constitutional proprieties of the limitations that the Senate should impose upon itself on such important matters. Perhaps he will be remembered most of all as someone who was prepared to honour the principles for which he stood irrespective of the damage that this may have caused to his parliamentary and political prospects.

In the world of politics these days when perhaps pragmatism has assumed a higher profile than the principles we often have, Alan Missen always stayed with his principles. That, of course, is a very important aspect of his characteristics which we should recognise. It is one of the reasons why he enjoyed the support, and the recognition of his integrity, of members of the Government party. I recall the difficulties he had in dealing with the Indonesian invasion of Portuguese East Timor and the difficulties he had, with his Government, and which many of us have in our Government, about the imprisonment for almost two decades of the Indonesian Foreign Minister, Dr Subandrio. Nevertheless he found, as we have found, that our philosophies have to be examined within the constraints placed upon us in terms of the way governments act in these matters.

I respected him as a person, at the personal level, and as a member of the Senate. He was one of the few early members of the Liberal Party of Australia to remain in politics. I agree with the contributions made so far by those on his side of politics: Despite his long-standing health problem he remained an active, progressive and highly principled member of the Parliament who will long be remembered for his activities in the human rights area and for his contributions to debates on the trade practices legislation and the Human Rights Commission. One can echo without any question the generous remarks made by a former senator, John Wheeldon, who, in an obituary in the Australian recently, described him as one of the Parliament's truly independent spirits.

I regret his passing because he stood for many issues that transcend party politics. He was unflinching in his support of those many principles upon which we enjoy common views. I regret his passing not only in relation to those principles but also because we have lost a fine senator, a fine human being, and the Parliament, as indeed is the community of Australia, is the loser by his untimely death. I pass on to his family my personal condolences. I know I speak on behalf of all of us in this chamber in expressing our great sympathy at his passing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to associate myself with this condolence motion. However, I believe that the very presence of Senator Missen in the chamber betokened something much more than his physical aspect, the figure of the man. There was a great moral strength there, so we will all be very conscious of his passing.

SPEECH.PARA: I entered the Parliament in 1978 and I believe that immediately I became a firm friend of Senator Missen, across the political divisions. I say I believe I became a friend, because it was a friendship which was always rather disconcerting because it put demands upon one that one was never quite sure one could fulfil. Just when one thought one was getting along quite fine, he would get a bee in his bonnet which was absolutely impossible to dispel; an infuriating obstinacy would set in and the limits of friendship would be tested. Not least do I recall this in relation to the inquiry into the National Crime Authority Bill, which has also been mentioned by Senator Chipp. I chaired that committee. I well recall the endless arguments we had as Senator Missen refused to have his recommendations and conclusions labelled a dissenting report. As far as he was concerned his conclusions and recommendations were quite equal to any others; they were of quite equal status to the conclusions of the other seven members of that Senate committee and it was just unfortunate that his conclusions happened to have been put forward by a minority, in this case one member. So we departed from the usual custom concerning Senate reports and did not label his views of one as a dissenting report. It was the only way we could get the report published. Nevertheless the friendship survived, I believe because of the tremendous respect in which he was held.

I mention, as have already been mentioned many times, two monuments to Alan Missen, in a parliamentary sense. His chairmanship of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs laid the groundwork for those monuments. TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alan Missen may not have been a paragon. Indeed, to many of us, as Senator Gareth Evans said earlier, he was something of an irritant-if not a constant one, at least a regular one-but he was a man from whom, as others have said today, we could learn a lot. SPEECH.PARA: Alan taught me one of the first lessons in politics that year. Alan looked up at me and, with what I suppose was mild cynicism, said `Ah, but who reads the legislation, hmmm?', with that purse-lipped hum which Alan would offer all of us and which meant: `I hope you have learned a lesson from that and I am probably the first one to have pointed it out to you anyway.'

He also taught me a lesson the last time I saw him. It was the last sitting day before this one, and I happened to be at the airport with him and subsequently on a plane to Melbourne. In the period that all of this took place Alan and I had been discussing my concern about being late for a meeting I was supposed to be attending that night. Alan spent some time telling me that I was foolish to worry about being late. For a start, it was beyond my control and, secondly, I should not worry generally about trying to appeal to people who essentially were bigots or extremists. To him, one either ignored them or fought them. I think that was what Alan did most of all. He refused to be worried about how people would perceive him and whether what he did was approved by them or not. If he did not agree with them, he simply fought them.

Senator Evans when he was speaking earlier said that not all of Alan Missen's causes got off the ground. I guess that that could be true of all of us. The important thing about Alan was that he never worried about that as an issue either. I was impressed too by the form the service took. I do not know whether Alan, as some people do, had any input into the form of thanksgiving service he wanted when he died. I suspect that he did not because Alan was not, it seemed to me, the sort of person to whom self-aggrandisement or self-congratulation was very high on the list of priorities. The little sheet that was given to us when we arrived had on the front: `A service of thanksgiving for the life and work of Alan Joseph Missen, senator for Victoria, champion of human rights'. I do not think that it is insignificant that the officiating clergy included people such as the Archbishop of Melbourne, the Most Reverend David Penman-himself, I suppose, a noted liberal thinker; the Right Reverend Peter Hollingworth, Director of the Brotherhood of St Laurence, whose commitment to social justice is well known; the Reverend Andrew St John, Vicar of Holy Trinity; and the Reverend Carlie Hannah, one of the first women to be ordained into the Anglican Church. I think that that set of officiating clergy would have satisfied Alan enormously. But along with that, as Senator Collard has already mentioned, a number of the sections of the service were particularly appropriate. Who would true valour see
Let him come hither;
One here will constant be,
Come wind, come weather;
There's no discouragement
Shall make him once relent
His first avow'd intent
To be a pilgrim.

Pilgrims are not easy to get on with. In fact, I would say-having never been one but having looked at a few such as Alan-that it is not easy to be one. But nobody and no thing deterred him from that. For those honourable senators who, perhaps, are not familiar with what being a pilgrim is all about, I say that a pilgrim is someone who goes on a journey for a sacred purpose. I think that the question of human rights, for Alan, was a sacred purpose. The hymn finishes with these three lines:
He'll not fear what men say;
He'll labour night and day
To be a pilgrim.

Alan did that. He was not a paragon. He was an ordinary human being, with, perhaps, fewer faults than most of us; but that is essentially all that he was-a human being. The important thing about Alan was that he recognised that there were other human beings with similar rights, similar values and similar entitlements to life, and he fought for those, as many of us would like to do but, perhaps, do not have the same commitment or that same balance about which Senator Gareth Evans spoke earlier. It is, after all, easier for most of us to swim with the tide, to protect our backs, to excuse our lack of action by saying things such as `The time is not right yet', or, `Maybe if we leave it a little while we can pick up a few more to come with us'; to take a pragmatic stance on the things in which we believe.

Alan's integrity and compassion and his deep belief in the value of individual human rights would not allow him to do that sort of thing. While all of us agree that he was not an easy man to live with and to work with, or even to know, it is important that we use him, as Senator Puplick said, as a touchstone, as someone whose actions we should aspire to emulate, as someone whose values are worthwhile copying, as a person who has probably done more for humankind in his 60 years than most of us could do if we lived to be twice that age. In saying that, I think there is all the more reason to extend to Mollie our deepest sympathy. She was, in fact, a helpmeet to Alan in the broadest sense of that term, sharing his commitment to the things that he believed in. Her life will be particularly empty without him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many of us enter these debates on motions of condolence often relying on the words of our leaders to speak for us all, but this will not do for Alan Missen. No one else in this place in my time here has approached his determination to act in this way. We could use for Alan Missen, not as an epithet of criticism or rebuke, but in the very best sense, the words written by Thomas Carlyle in 1837 about Robespierre, that he was `sea-green incorruptible'.

He was not easy to deal with on issues if an honourable senator was on the other side-and many senators have made references to this fact-but it was seldom difficult to understand the basis on which he had formed his view or to see the principle which was guiding him, even if one disagreed completely with what he was saying. His adherence to principle was demonstrated very well as early as 1951, when he risked his political career and his future place in politics to campaign against the referendum proposal to outlaw the Communist Party. I was too young to vote at that stage, but that was when I first heard of Alan Missen. Appalled by the anti-liberal and anti-democratic sentiments of that referendum proposal, I was pleased that Liberals as prominent and as clear-thinking as Alan Missen broke ranks to oppose the referendum successfully. In that and in similar stands on other issues he was a powerful continuing voice of the tradition of liberal, democratic thought and practice that brought many of us to this side of politics.

Alan Missen's personal courage was very great. His actions were taken always with complete disregard for any adverse effects they might have for him personally. Not surprisingly, but sadly, he was at times a lonely person in his public life. Other speakers have referred to this already. Some of us managed to become closer to Alan in the last year or two of his life. It was a privilege for us to give to and receive mutual support from Alan and Mollie on political and philosophical matters.

Alan came to me for medical counsel. Indeed, we discussed some of his very considerable health problems by telephone at some length just three days before he died. It is sufficient to say here that his health was very bad for a long time, that he had borne a heart attack privately-secretly-and that the one thing that seemed to improve his physical state most was a good stoush on an issue, whether it occurred in the chamber, in the Party room-particularly, I suspect, in the Party room-or on a committee. He never looked better than when he had been in a good fight.

Alan was a singular Liberal. He was one of the very few still active in the political life of Australia who had been involved in the formation of the Liberal Party of Australia. An examination of some of the things Menzies said and wrote in the days of the formation of the Party tells us something about Alan Missen and places him in context. Menzies said at that time:
There is no room in Australia for a party of reaction . . .
Alan Missen believed that. In The Forgotten People Menzies said:

. . . [while] individual enterprise must drive us forward. That does not mean that we are to return to the old and selfish notions of laissez-faire. The functions of the state will be much more than merely keeping the ring within which the competitors will fight. Our social and industrial obligations will be increased. There will be more law, not less, more control, not less.
Those were Menzies' words, but they describe Missen's view of liberalism and of the country. Menzies also said:
We took the name Liberal because we were determined to be a progressive party, willing to make experiments and in no sense reactionary.

Alan Missen was active then, in 1944. He was active in writing the early documents that defined the Liberal Party of Australia. He was imprinted for all his life with the early Menzian views. He was a traditional Liberal-people have used different words today such as `Gladstonian', `Mills', `a Deakinian Liberal'-as many of us today consider ourselves still to be. Australia was the beneficiary of this commitment and philosophy. Alan Missen, except when suspended for his stands on principle, was a continuous member of the Liberal Party from its formation to his death. He was always right in his total opposition to the Communist Party dissolution referendum in 1951. Let us say it: The Party was totally wrong, not only on the issue, but also in punishing Alan Missen for his opposition to its stand. After all, if we eschew the tyranny of the Caucus-our political opponents have the Caucus-if we will not have a bar of that system, we must accept the consequences of people acting to exercise the right of dissent that the freedom of our Party and our philosophy provide, and we must do so without punishing them. Alan Missen was prominent in the Party councils. He served the nation for 12 years in this place. He was a singular senator. He was one of a small class of dedicated parliamentarians, institutional senators, who served the Parliament and its institutions first and foremost. Perhaps it was inevitable that he gained no preferment. Perhaps, as Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has said, it is just as well that he was not asked to submit to the Cabinet discipline or to the rule of Cabinet government. That was not very important, however, as he made a lasting contribution to this Senate and to the institution of parliamentary democracy in Australia with his work, especially his work on the committees of this place. I think particularly of his commitment to the two legislative scrutiny standing committees-the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, of which he had been Chairman, and the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, whose establishment he promoted enthusiastically.

He was by nature, as someone else has said, an issues senator. Issues were what drove him on. As Senator Puplick said, he was quixotic. He was determined, passionate and powerful on a range of causes which have been mentioned, and which ranged from family law to freedom of information, human rights, Amnesty, the Human Rights Commission in particular, the National Crime Authority, South West Tasmania, law and social reform, and Aboriginal issues. My leader, Senator Chaney, will recall the struggles of 1976 as we put the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act in place, and other issues affecting the environment.

Mr President, to the extent that any funeral can be good, Alan Missen had a splendid funeral. He would have been pleased that so many people attended. He would have been pleased that the Archbishop of Melbourne honoured him by attending. He would have been delighted that his friend Bishop Peter Hollingworth officiated. He would have glowed at the magnificent tributes, the words spoken about him, by parliamentary colleagues such as Ian Macphee, his former parliamentary colleague Peter Block and the very eloquent words spoken by his old friend Peter Frankel. He would have enjoyed, as Senator Haines and others have said, the choice of service. He would have enjoyed the tribute paid to him by Amnesty International. He would have been pleased that Mollie Missen was able to know of the real regard, respect and affection that so many people held for him. Alan Missen was a well qualified, well equipped, fearless and committed servant of Australia and of this place. We shall all miss him.

One would have been wrong, and I was wrong on many occasions, in thinking of him as such. One thing he was not was deliberately destructive. He thought that his contributions were part of a constructive pattern.
