When some of the committee members asked me what I thought about discrimination in clubs I said: `I thought the whole idea of having a club was to discriminate'. I remember that Alan said to me: `Trust you to say something like that'. I remember also that some men's clubs were under discussion at the time and I was reading their aims and objectives and rules and regulations. Alan wanted to let women into men's clubs and his argument prevailed. However I pointed out that the second of one particular club's aims and objectives was to promote intercourse among members. In any case, Senator Alan Missen never seemed to give the amount of weight to my political views that I thought they deserved.

However, he gave weight to my opinions as a doctor. I attended to a number of his minor illnesses in this place and whenever he introduced me to people he would say: `Oh, I must tell you the story about the time I swallowed my false teeth'. He did swallow them-it was at dinner here one night. He came up to me and he was shaking a bit-I think the incident must have upset him. He seemed surprised when I asked him what course he was eating. He told me it was dessert and I told him: `You do not need a lot of teeth for that'. I told him to put himself in my hands and I would treat him with `some masterly inactivity and a bit of watchful expectancy'. I added: `You keep your eye on things and they should come out all right'. He did and they did and he seemed very happy. I also remember that when I first came here I started playing tennis at lunch time. Alan had not played for years but he decided that this was a great idea. He loved the game and he turned into a useful player. He played in the inaugural game between the Senate and the House of Representatives and in subsequent matches. He enjoyed the sport and I was very pleased that he did.

I remember the gusto and enthusiasm with which Alan Missen used to attack his committee work. It has already been mentioned here today. He seemed capable of enormous amounts of work; he just drank it up and poured out the results. I am pleased to hear that other people were helped by him by way of explanation in lots of areas. In family law particularly I always used him as my consultant and I found his advice was always spot on and very helpful. He always had that independence of mind and spirit that has been mentioned here this afternoon and I know he travelled the world for Amnesty International. He had many meetings here in Parliament House. I am an active non-member of Amnesty International. He had lots of meetings here and I always used to go to them. He always seemed so grateful and he always thanked me most kindly for doing that sort of thing. I think in his case 60 years was not a long time. We are just lucky to have been able to travel part of that journey with him. I extend my love, my sympathy and my condolences to Mollie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish briefly to speak to the condolence motion. I knew Alan for less than five years but I worked a lot with him during that time on the Tasmanian dams case, which has been referred to earlier today, on the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, on the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, for a short term the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, a monitoring committee, and Amnesty International. We developed a firm friendship and he greatly influenced my life.

SPEECH.PARA: I was not going to be anecdotal but Senator Tate spurred my memory of one small story concerning Alan's dissenting report to the National Crime Authority committee report and our joint experience in relation to that matter. I was recently on an aircraft with Alan and he mentioned to me that he was suing a particular newspaper for calling him, in part, a maverick. I said: `But Alan, I would have thought that you would have appreciated that'. He responded in a fury because, of course, Alan did not see himself as a maverick. It was the others who were mavericks, to such an extent that he was prepared to take out a writ.

I also admired Alan as a parliamentarian rather than a politician. The Parliament was always his forum, not the lobbies, the Party room, the media or whatever else. The public forum of parliament was precious to Alan Missen and, as has been said today, he had the intellectual capacity to use it well. Because it was so precious to him he constantly worked for its improvement and I admired him for that. His challenge was always how the Parliament could work more effectively and act as the greatest safeguard of individual liberty that we have.

It has also been said here today that Alan was a reformer. There was little that Alan saw that could not be improved; the law, the institutions or the Constitution. Nothing was sacred. As has also been said, he was always the energetic reformer, regrettably, a rarity in Australian society, and I admired him for that. He was a great civil libertarian. His passion was to give the individual a fighting chance over the ever-engulfing bureaucracy and government, which we saw through his work in the areas of freedom of information, administrative law reform, consumer protection legislation and other activities which will always be part of his legacy.

I also admired his productivity. He was a prodigious worker. I had trouble keeping my head above the mass of papers he constantly sent to me and I admired his capacity particularly at a time when I and all others here knew that he was not in good health. He was an activist, not just a talker. I just reflect upon Alan going to the Soviet Union and smuggling out documents to assist dissidents. Alan did not simply talk in the Parliament or in other forums. He actually got out into the community and participated and worked towards the achievement of his goals.

He was a great fighter for human rights. We saw it in his work in so many areas of the world-as I think was said by Senator Puplick-in the Soviet Union, East Timor, Sri Lanka, South Africa and elsewhere. We saw it particularly in his work in Amnesty International, and I admired him for that. At the time of his death he was Chairman of the Amnesty International parliamentary group, the first AI parliamentary group in the world. That group has written a short tribute to him which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard as part of my speech.
Leave granted.
The tribute read as follows-
AMNESTY INTERNATIONAL AUSTRALIA
6th Floor, 262 Pitt Street, Sydney NSW 2000
PO Box A159, Sydney South NSW 2000
4 April 1986
Senator The Hon. D. McClelland,
President of the Senate,
Parliament House,
Canberra,
ACT 2600
Dear Mr President,

Amnesty International Australia wishes to record its great appreciation for the late Sen. Alan Missen's many years of active support, through his involvement with the Amnesty International Parliamentary group.

At the time of his death, Alan Missen was Chairman of the Parliamentary Group, a position he had held for the past three years. He had been actively involved with the work of the group from its earliest days.

Reflecting the universality of human rights, and the impartiality of the work of Amnesty International, Alan successfully drew together members from all parties in the Federal Parliament to join the group. His commitment to parliamentarians forming Amnesty International groups was further evidenced, as he assisted with the establishment of some of the State parliamentary groups. In July 1985, he addressed the 18th World Conference of the Society for International Development, in Rome, on the work of the Australian Federal Parliamentary group, urging the establishment of similar groups in other Parliaments around the world.
Hansard will record that Alan Missen's last speech to the Senate referred to human rights. In that speech on 20 March 1986, he turned his attention to Afghanistan.

Alan Missen had called for an end to human rights violations wherever they occurred. Recently he had urged against the refoulment of Tamils to Sri Lanka. He spoke strongly in support of Amnesty International's human rights concerns in East Timor, El Salvador, South Africa, USSR and the treatment of the Turkish minority in Bulgaria.
He also actively sought Australia's unconditional ratification of international human rights agreements and their subsequent appropriate implementation in Australia.

Alan Missen leaves more than the record of his words in Hansard. His legacy will be measured by the future actions of members of the Parliament on behalf of the victims of human rights violations throughout the world.
Yours sincerely, Eric Moxham,
President,
Amnesty International Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. It is possible, of course, to go on and to mention so many good causes and so many achievements. What strikes me so much is his achievements in barely a decade in this Parliament. I reflect that it is so much more than the achievements of so many who have claimed higher office in this place. To him what he was trying to do went to the real essence of contemporary liberalism, and I believe he was right. I will miss him greatly. The last few words he spoke to me were said when he left this building on our last day of sitting. Of course, he believed that he was heading off to Rome during the two non-sitting weeks to pursue a human rights lecture. He asked me to look after his interests whilst he was away, as I suspect he asked a few others to do. Certainly, in my modest way I will attempt to do that in the years that lie ahead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Every Wednesday morning, in session, at 8.30 Senator Missen's health would improve, that is if the comment by my cousin, Senator Peter Baume, is accurate-that a good stoush would stimulate him. Senator Crowley and he always had a very interesting meeting in the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. Alan would go out of that meeting with his eyes sparkling, victory or not under his belt. He had, in that Committee which he was so instrumental in creating, a determination to ensure that the Executive, which at no stage he believed ever could be trusted, should be held in check. If there was a hint of retrospectivity or a sniff of a reverse onus of proof, or any suggestion of anything unduly oppressive, somehow it would jump out of the page at Alan Missen and he would then jump at the Executive. Without singling out the clerks in this place, he had a great dislike of the clerks who sought to oppress us, meaning clerks in the much more general sense. He regarded the bureaucracy as the clerks who sought to confuse the Parliament, to mislead us and certainly to lead us astray.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that so many people here today should have felt the need to speak, the desire to speak in this eulogy, this debate. It is, to my knowledge, the longest such debate that has been held. It is interesting that so many of us have sought to identify, one way or another, with the virtues that we saw in Alan Missen. I, for example, had always felt close to him on the score that we had both violently opposed the dissolution of the Communist Party and had spoken against the referendum on it. I, like Senator John Button, had the pleasure of debating against that formidable duo of Alan and his wife, Mollie.

It does seem that many of us who have felt that we have made accommodations in order to achieve things here have made accommodations that Alan Missen would not have made. I think many of us appear to be thinking that it was wrong to have made those accommodations, that in fact the way of purity, the way of determination that was Alan's whereby in fact he would refuse to lose a battle even if it would enhance his opportunity of winning a war, was right. We are behaving as if that were of necessity the right way and ours the wrong way. May I say that, while I think it is essential that any chamber such as ours should have someone who is so clearly its conscience, none of us should denigrate the contribution of those of us who do make those concessions to, if one might call it, reality, who do acknowledge that there are times when one must, if one seeks to achieve one's objective, resile from one's principles because one's long term objective is uppermost in our minds. Let us not, surely, by acknowledging and respecting the determination of Alan Missen never to give way on a matter of principle, by default suggest that the objectives of those of us in both parties here which in many cases oblige us to swallow our pride, to hold down our principles and to stick together are not worth while and wholly proper objectives.

I would like to join my colleagues in identifying, where I can, with Alan Missen in the things that I must say I wish I had been better at, the things that he was much better at than I am. Perhaps in many instances I should have stuck more to the principles which I thought were important but which I suppressed because I thought that there was another long term goal. I do feel that, as Ian Macphee said in his eulogy at the funeral, Alan Missen was an outstanding parliamentarian but he was less successful as a politician. I hope those of us who acknowledge the outstanding contribution that Alan Missen made do not in any way diminish our own achievements in this place.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 10 October 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has evidence of bias been found in the scaling system employed to calculate Tertiary Entrance Scores (TES) in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT); if so,

(a) is this bias exhibited by the fact that the relationship between the TES and the Australian Scholastic Aptitude Test (ASAT) scores of groups of boys and girls depend upon the sex ratio of the groups in which they studied; and
(b) has the Technical Advisory Committee of the ACT Accrediting Agency recommended to that Agency a method by which this bias can be considerably reduced, or eliminated; if so,

(i) did Dr Barry McGaw, an independent expert on educational measurement support that recommendation, as did the representatives of the Australian National University and the Canberra College of Advanced Education, and
(ii) has the Agency refused to accept that advice on two occasions recently.

(2) What measures does the Agency intend to take to remove the bias, if present, in its Tertiary Entrance Scores in 1985 and subsequent years, or will the sex ratio of courses not of itself affect the TES of students taking these courses.

(3) Will groups of girls (or boys) who have studied in a predominantly female (or male) group have TES strictly comparable with those gained by girls (or boys) who have studied in a group where neither sex predominates.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The following response has been provided to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is evidence of bias in the calculation of Tertiary Entrance Scores (TES) in mixed sex colleges in the ACT. When the mixed sex colleges are divided on a gender basis females do better on TES than would be predicted by their ASAT scores and males achieve lower TES than predicted.

(a) Students in single sex course groups do not have the opportunity to gain an advantage by performing at higher level than students of the opposite sex. In this sense the TES of males and females depends on the sex ratio of the college to which they belong.
This difference is only apparent when mixed sex colleges are divided on the basis of sex. There is a direct mathematical relationship between the ASAT and TES means which holds true for all colleges.

(b) The Technical Advisory Committee has recommended to the Accrediting Agency that ASAT scores should be adjusted so that they provide a better prediction of TES in mixed sex colleges. This would be achieved by increasing female ASAT scores and decreasing male ASAT scores, thus setting the measure of bias in mixed sex colleges to zero. The procedure would have little effect on the TES of males and females in mixed sex colleges, the greatest effect would be on single sex colleges. TES for girls going to single sex colleges (St Clares, Merici and CCEGGS) would increase and TES of boys attending single sex colleges (Marist and St Edmunds) would decrease.
(i) The Technical Advisory Committee recommendation was considered at the June 1985 Accrediting Agency
(ii) meeting and rejected. At that time the proposal was only supported by the ANU representative. Dr McGaw, who is a member of the Accrediting Agency, did not support the proposal.

At a Special Agency meeting in September the ANU and CCAE representatives put forward a motion to rescind the June decision. Effectively, passing this motion would have re-opened the question of the scaling rules to be applied in 1985. The minutes of that meeting show Dr McGaw's position:
``Dr McGaw said that he would on balance, with considerable equivocation, support calibration. He expressed doubts about:
-the validity of transferring a pattern of observed gender differences in mixed sex colleges to single sex colleges;
-the correctness of the measure of gender difference obtained from the mixed sex colleges.
The Technical Advisory Committee's answer to these questions is not convincing.

The Agency is faced with the difficulty that there is a difference between ASAT and TES in the way they measure gender differences. Variability in gender differences is greater for ASAT than for TES''.
(2) No changes were be made to the scaling process in 1985 as the Accrediting Agency and the principals of the colleges which
(3) issue Year 12 Certificates were not convinced that the Technical Advisory Committee proposal provided the most appropriate solution to the differences observed in mixed sex colleges.

However, in order that the Authority may decide how the differences in mixed sex colleges should be most appropriately addressed, the ACT Schools Authority, the Australian National University and the Canberra College of Advanced Education are jointly sponsoring two initiatives concerning policies for the calculation of Tertiary Entrance Scores of ACT Year 12 Certificates students.

First, a Committee has been set up to determine if there is evidence of systematic biases in the calculation of TES scores; to examine the reasons for any such biases and to recommend on a method or methods to overcome significant effects including such factors as sex, subject choice, and choice of school. Dr Barry McGaw, Director of ACER, is chairing the committee which includes representatives of each of the institutions, a tertiary student, and a secondary student.

The second and related initiative is to commission a series of research studies from the Centre for the Study of Higher Education of Melbourne University, under the leadership of Professor David Beswick.
Both exercises are to be completed by May so that informed decisions may be taken in respect of scaling scores for the 1986 Year 12 Certificate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Territories, upon notice, on 7 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has evidence of bias been found in the scaling system employed to calculate Tertiary Entrance Scores (TES) in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT); if so, is this bias exhibited by the fact that the relationship between the TES and the Australian Scholastic Aptitude Test (ASAT) scores of groups of boys and girls depends upon the sex ratio of the groups in which they studied.
(2) Has the Technical Advisory Committee of the ACT Accrediting Agency recommended to that Agency a method by which this bias can be reasonably reduced, or eliminated.

(3) Did Dr Barry McGaw, an independent expert on educational measurement support that recommendation, as did the representatives of the Australian National University and the Canberra College of Advanced Education.
(4) Has the Agency refused to accept that advice on 2 occasions recently.

(5) Can the Minister for Education outline the steps that the Agency intends to take to remove the bias, if present, in its Tertiary Entrance Scores in 1985 and subsequent years, or can the Minister give an assurance that under the system to be employed in 1985 and subsequent years the sex ratio of courses will not of itself affect the TES of students taking those courses.

(6) How does the use of an acknowledged sexually biased score as a basis for tertiary entrance accord with the Government's policy on Affirmative Action, and is not the Australian National University a participant in the pilot scheme on Affirmative Action in Universities.

(7) If the Minister is not able to act for 1985 Year 12 students, will she describe what actions she will take to compensate those for whom the failure to remove bias from the scores has denied them the opportunity to enter tertiary institutions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The following response has been provided to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is evidence of bias in the calculation of Tertiary Entrance Scores (TES) in mixed sex colleges in the ACT. When the mixed sex colleges are divided on a gender basis females do better on TES than would be predicted by their ASAT scores and males achieve lower TES than predicted.

Students in single sex course groups do not have the opportunity to gain an advantage by performing at a higher level than students of the opposite sex. In this sense the TES of males and females depends on the sex ratio of the college to which they belong.
This difference is only apparent when mixed sex colleges are divided on the basis of sex. There is a direct mathematical relationship between the ASAT and TES means which holds true for all colleges.

(2) The Technical Advisory Committee has recommended to the Accrediting Agency that ASAT scores should be adjusted so that they provide a better prediction of TES in mixed sex colleges. This would be achieved by increasing female ASAT scores and decreasing male ASAT scores, thus setting the measure of bias in mixed sex colleges to zero. The procedure would have little effect on the TES of males and females in mixed sex colleges, the greatest effect would be on single sex colleges. TES for girls going to single sex colleges (St Clares, Merici and CCEGGS) would increase and TES of boys attending single sex colleges (Marist and St Edmunds) would decrease.

(3) and (4) The Technical Advisory Committee recommendation was considered at the June 1985 Accrediting Agency meeting and rejected. At that time the proposal was only supported by the ANU representative. Dr McGaw, who is a member of the Accrediting Agency, did not support the proposal.

At a Special Agency meeting in September the ANU and CCAE representatives put forward a motion to rescind the June decision. Effectively, passing this motion would have reopened the question of the scaling rules to be applied in 1985. The minutes of that meeting show Dr McGaw's position:
``Dr McGaw said that he would on balance, with considerable equivocation, support calibration. He expressed doubts about:
- the validity of transferring a pattern of observed gender differences in mixed sex colleges to single sex colleges;
- the correctness of the measure of gender difference obtained from the mixed sex colleges.
The Technical Advisory Committee's answer to these questions is not convincing.

The Agency is faced with the difficulty that there is a difference between ASAT and TES in the way they measure gender differences. Variability in gender differences is greater for ASAT than for TES''.

(5) No changes were to be made to the scaling process in 1985 as the Accrediting Agency and the principals of the colleges which issue Year 12 Certificates were not convinced that the Technical Advisory Committee proposal provided the most appropriate solution to the differences observed in mixed sex colleges.

However, in order that the Authority may decide how the differences in mixed sex colleges should be most appropriately addressed, the ACT Schools Authority, the Australian National University and the Canberra College of Advanced Education are jointly sponsoring two initiatives concerning policies for the calculation of Tertiary Entrance Scores of ACT Year 12 Certificate students.

First, a Committee has been set up to determine if there is evidence of systematic biases in the calculation of TES scores; to examine the reasons for any such biases and to recommend on a method or methods to overcome significant effects including such factors as sex, subject choice, and choice of school. Dr Barry McGaw, Director of ACER, is chairing the committee which includes representatives of each of the institutions, a tertiary student, and a secondary student.
The second and related initiative is to commission a series of research studies from the Centre for the Study of Higher Education of Melbourne University, under the leadership of Prof. David Beswick.
Both exercises are to be completed by May so that informed decisions may be taken in respect of scaling scores for the 1986 Year 12 Certificate.

(6) The ANU is a participant in the pilot scheme on affirmative action in universities. However, the Government's policy on affirmative action relates to employment. Students are selected for tertiary places on the basis of merit determined by their performance. All parties concerned with the calculation and use of tertiary entrance scores are concerned that they be calculated on the most equitable basis possible.

(7) The 1985 ACT Tertiary Entrance Scores were calculated according to the agreed and published procedures. They were part of the information provided to tertiary institutions to assist them in the selection of students. The institutions are responsible for the actual selection and each tertiary institution applies its own criteria. Accordingly, there is no question of providing compensation for any students not selected by tertiary institutions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 12 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are all the measures of assistance outlined in Recommendation 58 of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking now being provided to officers of Customs engaged on primary line duties; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Recommendation 58 of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking states:

58. Officers of Customs engaged on primary line duties should have provided and maintained the assistance recommended in the Commission's interim report No. 2 Passports. That assistance should comprise:
(i) substantial instruction on the detection of forged passports, visas and other travel documentation, including the security features provided in Australian passports;
(ii) when at international airports access to samples of foreign passports as a standard against which such passports tendered by passengers can be checked;

(iii) regular briefings both oral and in writing on current developments in the forgery of, and fraudulent practices in relation to, Australian and foreign passports, visas and other travel documentation including information obtained from overseas agencies; and

(iv) equipment such as retro-reflective viewers, ultra-violet scanners and the like for the detection of unauthorised alteration of, or interference with, passports, visas and other travel documentarion.
Initiatives taken by the Australian Customs Service (ACS) since the tabling of the Stewart Report substantially implement Recommendation 58 in that:

(i) All Primary Officers have been instructed in writing of the security features incorporated in Australian passports. A video film of the security features by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (DIEA) is screened for the benefit of Primary Officers.

(ii) An international publication depicting samples of forgeries of foreign travel documents has been arranged from an overseas source. Copies of this publication have been distributed to Primary Officers.

(iii) Officers of DIEA attend the arrival of most international flights. Close co-operation has developed between these officers and those of the ACS and a crossflow of relative information ensues. Primary Officers are briefed by Customs supervisors or officers of DIEA of any abnormalities detected. DIEA document fraud examiners regularly attend airports to provide briefing to ACS and DIEA officers.

(iv) Retro-reflective viewers are available at all entry points into Australia. Ultra-violet scanners are being incorporated in new primary line modules which are being progressively introduced into passenger examination areas throughout Australia.
In response to part (2) of Senator Missen's question No. 858: ``What improvements have been suggested by the Passport Commission'', I assume that he is referring to the Passport Committee.

If this is the case I can report that the Minister for Foreign Affairs agreed that a subset of data be made available to the (then) Department of Industry and Commerce for inclusion in the PASS system for use at points of entry in Australia by Primary Line Officers. This allows officers to check passport holder details, thereby ensuring the authenticity of Australian passports of Australian citizens arriving in Australia.
Primary Line Officers now have access to that data.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Alcohol Abuse Aboard Ships in Australian Waters

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 19 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What legislation or regulations cover alcohol consumption by officers and crew of sea-going vessels in Australian waters.
(2) Which authority has the power to enforce, laws or rules if any are in place, and what are the penalties for alcohol abuse aboard ships in Australian waters.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is no Australian legislation which prescribes whether or under what conditions alcohol may be consumed by crews of ships in Australian waters.
There are however a number of measures contained in the Navigation Act 1912 and subordinate legislation directed at the misuse of alcohol.
Section 99 of that Act provides for courts to impose fines or terms of imprisonment or both, for acts tending to endanger life or ship through drunkenness.

Section 115 empowers a ship's master to impose fines for specified breaches of shipboard discipline. Offences in this regard are specified in the Navigation (Master and Seamen) Regulations and include the offence of drunkenness.
A further provision in most ship's articles of agreement allows the master the option of instantly dismissing a crew member for such an offence instead of imposing a fine.

The Marine Council, a body established under section 424 of the Navigation Act, is charged with the duty of advising the Minister for Transport on the suitability of persons for engagement in Australian ships. Under sub-section 45A (9) of the Act, where the Council advises the Minister that a person is unsuitable, the person is prevented from engaging in ships to which the crewing provisions of the Act apply, in effect suspension from seagoing employment. The Council acts as the industry disciplinary body and has a policy of imposing periods of suspension, of greater or lesser degree according to the circumstances for cases of serious misconduct including misuse of alcohol.

The foregoing provisions apply to ships on interstate or overseas voyages and which are either Australian registered or foreign registered having the majority of the crew Australian resident and operated by Australian based interests.
Crews of foreign registered and manned ships in Australian waters are subject to the legislation of the flag State.
Laws of major maritime nations are in general similar to those of Australia in this respect.
For Australian ships on intrastate voyages the relevant State or Territory Maritime Legislation applies.

In addition to the martime laws described above, the crew of a ship in the territorial sea is subject to the criminal laws of the adjacent State or Territory and any provisions relating to the use of alcohol which those laws may contain.

(2) The Navigation Act is administered by the Department of Transport and a prosecution under the Act, if considered appropriate, would be brought by the Department. In practice, because of the nature of sea service with its separation in distance and time from shore based authority, it is only a ship's master who can exert any day to day influence on the use of alcohol on board.
Penalties for offences under the Navigation Act relating to drunkenness are:
on indictment under section 99, a fine not exceeding $5000 or imprisonment for a period not exceeding 2 years or both
fines imposed by a ship's master under section 115, $2 for first offence and $4 for each subsequent offence
under sub-section 45A (9), loss of seagoing employment for the period specified.
Instant dismissal under the terms of articles of agreement may involve considerable financial penalty as in these circumstances the seafarer is liable for his repatriation costs to his home port.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 November 1985 (Hansard, page 1654), Senator Archer asked me a two-part question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question was:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Government studied the revised rural income prediction of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics for 1985-86 that shows a decline of 26 per cent on the figure for 1984-85?
Does the Government believe that farmers can once again cover such a disastrous decline simply with greater efficiency?
The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The 26 per cent reduction in rural incomes referred to by Senator Archer is the forecast decline in the 1985-86 real net value of rural production that was published by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics in the November 1985 edition of the Quarterly Review of Rural Economy. Subsequent revision in the light of more recent data resulted in a marginal decline in the estimated reduction to 24 per cent, the figure presented at the National Agricultural Outlook Conference and published in the February issue of the Quarterly Review. The revised forecast was calculated from:
an estimated gross value of total rural production in 1985-86 of around $15 500 million, unchanged from 1984-85.
and an estimated 7 per cent increase in total farm costs in 1985-86 to around $12 000 million
which results in a forecast 19 per cent reduction in the net nominal value of total rural production to around $3 500 million.
After allowing for inflation, the real net value of rural production index is forecast to fall by 24 per cent.

One of the major factors contributing to the expected deterioration in the economic performance of the rural sector is the unfavourable outlook for the main broadacre cropping industries. For example, during 1985-86 the gross value of wheat production is forecast to decline by 12 per cent to $2920 million.

The lower gross income from wheat production mainly reflects an anticipated smaller crop. World wheat prices are estimated to decline significantly from their 1984-85 level, but this is expected to be offset by the lower value of the Australian dollar. During 1986 the world wheat market will come under increasing pressure as both the US and EC move to aggressively market their large exportable surpluses of wheat.

In comparison to the cropping sector, the prospects for the wool and meat industries are more favourable. The gross value of rural production for wool and livestock slaughterings is forecast to rise by 5 and 7 per cent respectively during 1985-86.

One of the most critical assumptions used in the preparation of these forecasts is the value of the Australian dollar exchange rate. In preparing these estimates it was assumed that the Australian dollar would average US 70 cents during 1985-86 compared with an exchange rate of US 77 cents in 1984-85.

To indicate the importance of the exchange rate assumption, should the value of the Australian dollar average around US 67 cents for the duration of 1985-86, the decline in the real net value of rural production would be around 20 per cent. The larger depreciation in the value of the Australian dollar would improve the prices received for exported commodities while at the same time increasing the cost of imported farm inputs.

The estimated decline in the net value of rural production for 1985-86 demonstrates, once again, the volatile nature of farm returns in Australia. Farmers can be expected to continue to take appropriate measures to deal with the large year-to-year fluctuations in incomes stemming from extreme variations in weather conditions and commodity prices. Such measures include the rapid adoption of productivity enhancing technological innovations, structural adjustments, the careful management of input usage and enterprise selection, and alterations to investment and consumption expenditure patterns to reflect changing revenue flows.

In view of the unfavourable medium term economic outlook for major export commodities, and the depressed financial situation of many farmers at present-just over one third of BAE surveyed farmers will have negative farm incomes in 1985-86-farmers cannot be expected to bear the full burden for adjustment. As the Prime Minister has announced, I shall be presenting a Ministerial Statement to Parliament on 15 April on rural policies placing these policies in the context of the Government's overall economic approach and containing specific measures to assist the rural sector with its current economic downturn.

(2) What guidelines did the Prime Minister give to the Departmental advisors who selected the delegates (see answer to Question on Notice No. 421, Hansard, 3 December 1985, p. 2865).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Parliamentarians chosen for the Australian Delegation to the Nairobi World Conference, including Senator Patricia Giles, the Head of the Delegation, were all women with a demonstrated interest in status of women issues. The Government was concerned to limit the size of the delegation yet at the same time ensure that it was as representative as possible. Accordingly it was necessary to restrict the number of Parliamentarian delegates. Indeed, there are precedents for governments choosing Parliamentarians from within their own ranks for such delegations. At the time of the Copenhagen Mid-Decade Conference in 1980 the Australian Delegation included two Parliamentarians, both from the Liberal Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 December 1985 (Hansard, page 2648) Senator Siddons asked me as Minister representing the Minister for Trade, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Government aware that a report published by Mr Paul Parker of the Australian National University estimates that government subsidies given to the Tasmanian export woodchip industry total $10m to $15m per annum? This represents $5 per tonne or 10 per cent of the value of the woodchips exported. How can this Government call on the European Economic Community to stop subsidising its farm exports while doing nothing about its woodchip subsidy, which is probably in contravention of our international trade obligations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and trade?
The Minister for Trade has provided the following response to the honourable senator's question:

Australia's GATT obligations with respect to subsidies are embodied in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade itself and the GATT Subsidies Code to which we acceded in 1981. The Subsidies Code, which elaborates on the provisions of the General Agreement, prohibits export subsidies on products other than ``certain primary products''. Export subsidies are permitted on these ``certain primary products'' provided they are not used in a manner which results in a member obtaining a more than equitable share of world trade. For the purposes of the Code, ``certain primary products'' are understood to be ``any product of farm, forest or fishery . . . in its natural form or which has undergone such processing as is customarily required to prepare it for marketing in substantial volume in international trade''.

The Code also recognises that subsidies other than export subsidies are widely used as important instruments for the promotion of social and economic policy objectives and does not seek to restrict the right of signatories to use such subsidies. However, it requires signatories in drawing up subsidy policies to weigh up, as far as practicable, possible adverse effects on trade and to seek to avoid causing injury or serious prejudice to the interests of other signatories.
Neither the Commonwealth nor, I am advised, the Tasmanian Government provide direct export subsidies to the Tasmanian woodchip export industry.
Possible avenues of indirect assistance were pointed out in a paper by the Centre for environmental Studies.

University of Tasmania and addressed by Mr Paul Parker of the Australian National University. The Supplement to the Draft Environmental Impact Statement on Tasmanian woodchip exports put forward a number of contrary arguments to those raised in the former documents. Indirect assistance through the provision of infrastructure is a common result of Government activities and it would appear to be governed, if at all, by the requirement not to injure the interests of other Subsidies Code signatories.

Prices for Australian woodchip exports are determined through commercial negotiations between exporters and buyers, subject to the guideline that prices must be consistent with prevailing market conditions. The Government is not aware of any complaints that Australian woodchip prices have unfairly prejudiced the interests of other Code signatories.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 February 1986 (Hansard, page 708) Senator Watson asked me as Minister representing the Minister for Trade, the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the Minister release a genuine and attainable current account target for the financial year so that Australians no longer will have to rely on media leaks of recommendations from the Government's joint economic forecasting group for such vital information? Could he indicate how other exports will rise or imports will fall by the huge amounts necessary to achieve the Government's revised target for 1985-86 of $11.25 billion?
The Minister for Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

As the Treasurer has announced, the Government now expects the current account deficit for 1985-86 as a whole to be somewhat greater than anticipated at budget-time. The main factor giving rise to this has been the strength of imports. However, the growth in imports has been concentrated in investment goods, with imports of consumer goods being virtually unchanged. Investment imports will, of course, be beneficial to economic growth and the correction of the external accounts in the longer term.

The Government expects that the improvement in competitiveness from the depreciation of the $A, together with the expected slowing in domestic demand, will lead to a significant improvement in the current account deficit in 1986 and beyond. The Government's economic policies, including the agreement between the Government and the ACTU, which involves a two year extension of the Prices and Incomes Accord and reduced wage indexation increases, will assist this process. Nevertheless, with five months of balance of payments data to come in for 1985-86, and the volatility that exists in the monthly numbers, the Government is not disposed to release a revised forecast for the current account deficit for 1985-86 at this stage.
